citations.narrative:
There were no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand available at the time of the inspection for the ducks,
turkeys, chickens, peacocks, quail, the 3 guinea pigs that are on the premises, and the one new pig and one new rabbit
that were acquired since the last inspection.
Per this Section of the Regulations, exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of the
acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers and the sources of the
animals. The Licensee needs to prepare records of acquisition and a record of animals on hand for these birds, guinea
pigs, pig, and rabbit and ensure that the animal records are kept current for all future animal acquisitions. Correct by
12/3/23.

The Contingency Plan available for review at the time of the inspection was still incomplete. The Licensee used APHIS
Form 7093 (USDA/APHIS/Animal Care Contingency Planning Program) to document the Contingency Plan, but the
sections of the form were blank where provide the details of the Plan for the situations that trigger implementation of the
Plan, the specific tasks/responsible person(s) for the tasks, and the specific resources needed to perform the tasks.
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling,
treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could
reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their
possession) and should have been in place by 7/5/22. The contingency plan requirement ensures that the animals receive
proper care during emergency situations.

Two of the rabbit primary enclosures are comprised of a house/pen placed on top of the ground. There is a panel of
coated wire mesh with ~1 ½” by 6” rectangular spacing that covers the dirt floor of each enclosure to prevent the 2 rabbits
from digging out of their enclosures. The coated wire mesh panel floor in each enclosure is exposed and not covered with
dirt/other substrate and poses a risk of injury to the rabbits from entrapment of the digits/feet/leg.
Per this Section, the floors of the primary enclosures shall be constructed so as to protect the rabbits’ feet and legs from
injury. The Licensee needs to address this item for the health and safety of the rabbits. Correct by 11/8/23.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the birds at the facility were socially housed and were provided with materials to enhance their environment, a
written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the birds had not been developed
and was not available for review at the time of the inspection.
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement
to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian and must be in
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference
guides. At a minimum, the plan must address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The Licensee needs to develop an environmental enrichment plan
appropriate for the species of birds maintained and the plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by
12/3/23.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
*END OF REPORT*
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There were no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand available at the time of the inspection for the ducks, 
turkeys, chickens, peacocks, quail, the 3 guinea pigs that are on the premises, and the one new pig and one new rabbit 
that were acquired since the last inspection.  
 
Per this Section of the Regulations, exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of the 
acquisition and disposition of animals in their possession in order to account for all animal transfers and the sources of the 
animals. The Licensee needs to prepare records of acquisition and a record of animals on hand for these birds, guinea 
pigs, pig, and rabbit and ensure that the animal records are kept current for all future animal acquisitions. Correct by 
12/3/23. 
2.134(a)  Repeat
   
Contingency planning. 
The Contingency Plan available for review at the time of the inspection was still incomplete. The Licensee used APHIS 
Form 7093 (USDA/APHIS/Animal Care Contingency Planning Program) to document the Contingency Plan, but the 
sections of the form were blank where provide the details of the Plan for the situations that trigger implementation of the 
Plan, the specific tasks/responsible person(s) for the tasks, and the specific resources needed to perform the tasks.  
 
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling, 
treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could 
reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their 
possession) and should have been in place by 7/5/22. The contingency plan requirement ensures that the animals receive 
proper care during emergency situations. 
3.53(a)(4) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two of the rabbit primary enclosures are comprised of a house/pen placed on top of the ground. There is a panel of 
coated wire mesh with ~1 ½” by 6” rectangular spacing that covers the dirt floor of each enclosure to prevent the 2 rabbits

from digging out of their enclosures. The coated wire mesh panel floor in each enclosure is exposed and not covered with 
dirt/other substrate and poses a risk of injury to the rabbits from entrapment of the digits/feet/leg. 
 
Per this Section, the floors of the primary enclosures shall be constructed so as to protect the rabbits’ feet and legs from 
injury. The Licensee needs to address this item for the health and safety of the rabbits. Correct by 11/8/23. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Although the birds at the facility were socially housed and were provided with materials to enhance their environment, a 
written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the birds had not been developed 
and was not available for review at the time of the inspection.  
 
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement 
to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian and must be in 
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference 
guides. At a minimum, the plan must address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special 
considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The Licensee needs to develop an environmental enrichment plan 
appropriate for the species of birds maintained and the plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by 
12/3/23. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
*END OF REPORT*
